newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Senate calls for new base accord with Panama.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Senate calls for new base accord with Panama.

text.p: The U.S. Senate has urged negotiation of a new base rights accord with Panama to enable the United States to maintain a military presence there beyond the year 2000.

A resolution approved late on Thursday said military facilities used by U.S. forces in Panama were critical in combatting narcotics trafficking and noted that the Navy depended on the Panama Canal in times of emergency.
It also said Panama maintained only a civilian police organisation to defend the canal and cited public opinion polls as suggesting many Panamanians wanted a continued U.S. military presence.
Under the Panama Canal treaties the United States must complete withdrawal of its forces from Panama after Dec. 31, 1999 unless a new agreement is reached.
Republican Senate Foreign Committee Chairman Jesse Helms of North Carolina said total U.S military withdrawal from Panama would leave the United States with no major military presence in the region.
"I have had a number of meetings with Panamanians," he told the Senate. "They want us to stay.
The Senate adopted the resolution without a formal vote. The House had passed it earlier.
